page.title: 15CHANGING FACE OF FARMING 2
page.content: THERE ALWAYS USED TO BE A HOUSE COW THAT WOULD PROVIDE THE MILK BUTTER AND CHEESE AS TO WAS A PIG. THESE HAVE NOW SADLY DISAPPEARED TOGETHER WITH THE COTTAGE GARDEN. IN THE CASE OF THE HOWARDS FARM THEY HAD LINCOLNSHIRE LONG WOOL SHEEP UP TO 1984, A FLOCK OF 200 MAINLY BREEDING EWES.THE WOOL WENT TO BRADFORD FOR THE WOOLEN INDUSTRY.THE LAMBS WERE FATTENED AND SOLD. THERE WAS ALSO 20 BREEDING SOWS UP TO 1975. E.E.C. FARMING RULES AND SUBSIDIES AVAILABLE HAVE ADDED TO THE CHANGES.THERE HAS ALSO BEEN AN AMAZING DROP IN THE WATER TABLE, WHERE AT ONE TIME IT WAS AT 15 FEET IT NOW REQUIRES A VAST ELECTRIC PUMP TO LIFT IT FROM 300 FEET. BECAUSE OF THE SANDY SOIL THERE IS NO NEED TO DID DITCHES IN THIS AREA. THE OLD CRAFT OF HEDGING IS NOW MECHANICAL.DUTCH BARNS HAVE SEEN ANOTHER OLD CRAFT IN THE FORM OF
